text: The proverbs of Solomon son of David, king of Israel:
speaker: Narrator

text:
For learning about wisdom and instruction,
    for understanding words of insight,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for gaining instruction in wise dealing,
    righteousness, justice, and equity;
speaker: Narrator

text:
to teach shrewdness to the simple,
    knowledge and prudence to the young—
speaker: Narrator

text:
let the wise, too, hear and gain in learning
    and the discerning acquire skill,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to understand a proverb and a figure,
    the words of the wise and their riddles.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge;
    fools despise wisdom and instruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear, my child, your father’s instruction,
    and do not reject your mother’s teaching,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for they are a fair garland for your head
    and pendants for your neck.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, if sinners entice you,
    do not consent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If they say, “Come with us, let us lie in wait for blood;
    let us wantonly ambush the innocent;
speaker: Narrator

text:
like Sheol let us swallow them alive
    and whole, like those who go down to the Pit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We shall find all kinds of costly things;
    we shall fill our houses with spoil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Throw in your lot among us;
    we will all have one purse”—
speaker: Narrator

text:
my child, do not walk in their way;
    keep your foot from their paths,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for their feet run to evil,
    and they hurry to shed blood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For in vain is the net baited
    while the bird is looking on;
speaker: Narrator

text:
yet they lie in wait—to kill themselves!
    and set an ambush—for their own lives!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Such is the end of all who are greedy for gain;
    it takes away the life of its possessors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom cries out in the street;
    in the squares she raises her voice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At the busiest corner she cries out;
    at the entrance of the city gates she speaks:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“How long, O simple ones, will you love being simple?
How long will scoffers delight in their scoffing
    and fools hate knowledge?
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Because I have called and you refused,
    have stretched out my hand and no one heeded,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and because you have ignored all my counsel
    and would have none of my reproof,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I also will laugh at your calamity;
    I will mock when panic strikes you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when panic strikes you like a storm
    and your calamity comes like a whirlwind,
    when distress and anguish come upon you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then they will call upon me, but I will not answer;
    they will seek me diligently but will not find me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Because they hated knowledge
    and did not choose the fear of the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text:
would have none of my counsel
    and despised all my reproof,
speaker: Narrator

text:
therefore they shall eat the fruit of their way
    and be sated with their own devices.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For waywardness kills the simple,
    and the complacency of fools destroys them;
speaker: Narrator

text:
but those who listen to me will be secure
    and will live at ease without dread of disaster.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, if you accept my words
    and treasure up my commandments within you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
making your ear attentive to wisdom
    and inclining your heart to understanding,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if you indeed cry out for insight
    and raise your voice for understanding,
speaker: Narrator

text:
if you seek it like silver
    and search for it as for hidden treasures—
speaker: Narrator

text:
then you will understand the fear of the Lord
    and find the knowledge of God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the Lord gives wisdom;
    from his mouth come knowledge and understanding;
speaker: Narrator

text:
he stores up sound wisdom for the upright;
    he is a shield to those who walk blamelessly,
speaker: Narrator

text:
guarding the paths of justice
    and preserving the way of his faithful ones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will understand righteousness and justice
    and equity, every good path,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for wisdom will come into your heart,
    and knowledge will be pleasant to your soul;
speaker: Narrator

text:
prudence will watch over you,
    and understanding will guard you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It will save you from the way of evil,
    from those who speak perversely,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who forsake the paths of uprightness
    to walk in the ways of darkness,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who rejoice in doing evil
    and delight in the perverseness of evil,
speaker: Narrator

text:
those whose paths are crooked
    and who are devious in their ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will be saved from the loose woman,
    from the adulteress with her smooth words,
speaker: Narrator

text:
who forsakes the partner of her youth
    and forgets her sacred covenant,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for her way leads down to death
    and her paths to the shades;
speaker: Narrator

text:
those who go to her never come back,
    nor do they regain the paths of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Therefore walk in the way of the good,
    and keep to the paths of the just.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the upright will abide in the land,
    and the innocent will remain in it,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but the wicked will be cut off from the earth,
    and the treacherous will be rooted out of it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, do not forget my teaching,
    but let your heart keep my commandments,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for length of days and years of life
    and abundant welfare they will give you.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Then you will find favor and high regard
    in the sight of God and of people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Trust in the Lord with all your heart,
    and do not rely on your own insight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In all your ways acknowledge him,
    and he will make straight your paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not be wise in your own eyes;
    fear the Lord and turn away from evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It will be a healing for your flesh
    and a refreshment for your body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Honor the Lord with your substance
    and with the first fruits of all your produce;
speaker: Narrator

text:
then your barns will be filled with plenty,
    and your vats will be bursting with wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, do not despise the Lord’s discipline
    or be weary of his reproof,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the Lord reproves the one he loves,
    as a father the son in whom he delights.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Happy are those who find wisdom
    and those who get understanding,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for her income is better than silver
    and her revenue better than gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is more precious than jewels,
    and nothing you desire can compare with her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Long life is in her right hand;
    in her left hand are riches and honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her ways are ways of pleasantness,
    and all her paths are peace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is a tree of life to those who lay hold of her;
    those who hold her fast are called happy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord by wisdom founded the earth;
    by understanding he established the heavens;
speaker: Narrator

text:
by his knowledge the deeps broke open,
    and the clouds drop down the dew.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, do not let these escape from your sight:
    keep sound wisdom and prudence,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and they will be life for your soul
    and adornment for your neck.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will walk on your way securely,
    and your foot will not stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you sit down, you will not be afraid;
    when you lie down, your sleep will be sweet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will not be afraid of sudden panic
    or of the storm that strikes the wicked,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the Lord will be your confidence
    and will keep your foot from being caught.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not withhold good from those to whom it is due,
    when it is in your power to do it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not say to your neighbor, “Go and come again;
    tomorrow I will give it,” when you have it with you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not plan harm against your neighbor
    who lives trustingly beside you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not quarrel with anyone without cause,
    when no harm has been done to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not envy the violent,
    and do not choose any of their ways,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the perverse are an abomination to the Lord,
    but the upright are in his confidence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord’s curse is on the house of the wicked,
    but he blesses the abode of the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Toward the scorners he is scornful,
    but to the humble he shows favor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise will inherit honor,
    but stubborn fools, disgrace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen, children, to a father’s instruction,
    and be attentive, that you may gain insight,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for I give you good precepts:
    do not forsake my teaching.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When I was a son with my father,
    tender and my mother’s favorite,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Get wisdom; get insight: do not forget nor turn away
    from the words of my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not forsake her, and she will keep you;
    love her, and she will guard you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The beginning of wisdom is this: get wisdom,
    and whatever else you get, get insight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Prize her highly, and she will exalt you;
    she will honor you if you embrace her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She will place on your head a fair garland;
    she will bestow on you a beautiful crown.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear, my child, and accept my words,
    that the years of your life may be many.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have taught you the way of wisdom;
    I have led you in the paths of uprightness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you walk, your step will not be hampered,
    and if you run, you will not stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Keep hold of instruction; do not let go;
    guard her, for she is your life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not enter the path of the wicked,
    and do not walk in the way of evildoers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Avoid it; do not go on it;
    turn away from it and pass on.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they cannot sleep unless they have done wrong;
    they are robbed of sleep unless they have made someone stumble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they eat the bread of wickedness
    and drink the wine of violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But the path of the righteous is like the light of dawn,
    which shines brighter and brighter until full day.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The way of the wicked is like deep darkness;
    they do not know what they stumble over.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, be attentive to my words;
    incline your ear to my sayings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not let them escape from your sight;
    keep them within your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For they are life to those who find them
    and healing to all their flesh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Keep your heart with all vigilance,
    for from it flow the springs of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Put away from you crooked speech,
    and put devious talk far from you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let your eyes look directly forward
    and your gaze be straight before you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Keep straight the path of your feet,
    and all your ways will be sure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not swerve to the right or to the left;
    turn your foot away from evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, be attentive to my wisdom;
    incline your ear to my understanding,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so that you may hold on to prudence,
    and your lips may guard knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the lips of a loose woman drip honey,
    and her speech is smoother than oil,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but in the end she is bitter as wormwood,
    sharp as a two-edged sword.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her feet go down to death;
    her steps follow the path to Sheol.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She does not keep straight to the path of life;
    her ways wander, and she does not know it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And now, my child, listen to me,
    and do not depart from the words of my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Keep your way far from her,
    and do not go near the door of her house,
speaker: Narrator

text:
lest you give your honor to others
    and your years to the merciless,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and strangers take their fill of your wealth,
    and your labors go to the house of an alien,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and at the end of your life you groan,
    when your flesh and body are consumed,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and you say, “Oh, how I hated discipline,
    and my heart despised reproof!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I did not listen to the voice of my teachers
    or incline my ear to my instructors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Now I am at the point of utter ruin
    in the public assembly.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Drink water from your own cistern,
    flowing water from your own well.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Should your springs be scattered abroad,
    streams of water in the streets?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let them be for yourself alone
    and not for sharing with strangers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let your fountain be blessed,
    and rejoice in the wife of your youth,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Why should you be intoxicated, my son, by another woman
    and embrace the bosom of an adulteress?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For human ways are under the eyes of the Lord,
    and he examines all their paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The iniquities of the wicked ensnare them,
    and they are caught in the coils of their sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They die for lack of discipline,
    and because of their great folly they are lost.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, if you have given your pledge to your neighbor,
    if you have bound yourself to another,
speaker: Narrator

text:
you are snared by the utterance of your lips,
    caught by the words of your mouth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Give your eyes no sleep
    and your eyelids no slumber;
speaker: Narrator

text:
save yourself like a gazelle from the hunter,
    like a bird from the hand of the fowler.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Go to the ant, you lazybones;
    consider its ways and be wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Without having any chief
    or officer or ruler,
speaker: Narrator

text:
it prepares its food in summer
    and gathers its sustenance in harvest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How long will you lie there, O lazybones?
    When will you rise from your sleep?
speaker: Narrator

text:
A little sleep, a little slumber,
    a little folding of the hands to rest,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and poverty will come upon you like a robber,
    and want, like an armed warrior.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A scoundrel and a villain
    goes around with crooked speech,
speaker: Narrator

text:
winking the eyes, shuffling the feet,
    pointing the fingers,
speaker: Narrator

text:
with perverted mind devising evil,
    continually sowing discord;
speaker: Narrator

text:
on such a one calamity will descend suddenly,
    in a moment, damage beyond repair.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are six things that the Lord hates,
    seven that are an abomination to him:
speaker: Narrator

text:
haughty eyes, a lying tongue,
    and hands that shed innocent blood,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a heart that devises wicked plans,
    feet that hurry to run to evil,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a lying witness who testifies falsely,
    and one who sows discord in a family.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, keep your father’s commandment,
    and do not forsake your mother’s teaching.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bind them upon your heart always;
    tie them around your neck.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
For the commandment is a lamp and the teaching a light,
    and the reproofs of discipline are the way of life,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to preserve you from the wife of another,
    from the smooth tongue of the adulteress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not desire her beauty in your heart,
    and do not let her capture you with her eyelashes,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for a prostitute’s fee is only a loaf of bread,
    but the wife of another stalks a man’s precious life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Can fire be carried in the bosom
    without burning one’s clothes?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Or can one walk on hot coals
    without scorching the feet?
speaker: Narrator

text:
So is he who sleeps with his neighbor’s wife;
    no one who touches her will go unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thieves are not despised who steal only
    to satisfy their appetite when they are hungry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet if they are caught, they will pay sevenfold;
    they will forfeit all the goods of their house.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But he who commits adultery has no sense;
    he who does it destroys himself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will get wounds and dishonor,
    and his disgrace will not be wiped away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For jealousy arouses a husband’s fury,
    and he will show no restraint when he takes revenge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will accept no compensation
    and will refuse a bribe no matter how great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, keep my words
    and store up my commandments with you;
speaker: Narrator

text:
keep my commandments and live;
    keep my teachings as the apple of your eye;
speaker: Narrator

text:
bind them on your fingers;
    write them on the tablet of your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Say to wisdom, “You are my sister,”
    and call insight your intimate friend,
speaker: Narrator

text:
that they may keep you from the loose woman,
    from the adulteress with her smooth words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For at the window of my house
    I looked out through my lattice,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and I saw among the simple ones,
    I observed among the youths,
    a young man without sense,
speaker: Narrator

text:
passing along the street near her corner,
    taking the road to her house
speaker: Narrator

text:
in the twilight, in the evening,
    at the time of night and darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then a woman comes toward him
    decked out like a prostitute, with hidden intent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is loud and wayward;
    her feet do not stay at home;
speaker: Narrator

text:
now in the street, now in the squares,
    and at every corner she lies in wait.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She seizes him and kisses him,
    and with impudent face she says to him:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I had to offer sacrifices,
    and today I have paid my vows;
speaker: Narrator

text:
so now I have come out to meet you,
    to seek you eagerly, and I have found you!
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have decked my couch with coverings,
    colored spreads of Egyptian linen;
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have perfumed my bed with myrrh,
    aloes, and cinnamon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come, let us take our fill of love until morning;
    let us delight ourselves with love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For my husband is not at home;
    he has gone on a long journey.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He took a bag of money with him;
    he will not come home until full moon.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
With much seductive speech she persuades him;
    with her smooth talk she compels him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Right away he follows her
    and goes like an ox to the slaughter
or bounds like a stag toward the trap
speaker: Narrator

text:
until an arrow pierces its entrails.
He is like a bird rushing into a snare,
    not knowing that it will cost him his life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And now, my children, listen to me,
    and be attentive to the words of my mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not let your hearts turn aside to her ways;
    do not stray into her paths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For many are those she has laid low,
    and numerous are her victims.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her house is the way to Sheol,
    going down to the chambers of death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Does not wisdom call
    and understanding raise her voice?
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the heights, beside the way,
    at the crossroads she takes her stand;
speaker: Narrator

text:
beside the gates in front of the town,
    at the entrance of the portals she cries out:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“To you, O people, I call,
    and my cry is to all who live.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O simple ones, learn prudence;
    acquire intelligence, you who lack it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear, for I will speak noble things,
    and from my lips will come what is right,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for my mouth will utter truth;
    wickedness is an abomination to my lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the words of my mouth are righteous;
    there is nothing twisted or crooked in them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are all straight to one who understands
    and right to those who find knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take my instruction instead of silver
    and knowledge rather than choice gold,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for wisdom is better than jewels,
    and all that you may desire cannot compare with her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I, wisdom, live with prudence,
    and I attain knowledge and discretion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fear of the Lord is hatred of evil.
Pride and arrogance and the way of evil
    and perverted speech I hate.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have good advice and sound wisdom;
    I have insight; I have strength.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By me kings reign,
    and rulers decree what is just;
speaker: Narrator

text:
by me rulers rule,
    and nobles, all who govern rightly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I love those who love me,
    and those who seek me diligently find me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Riches and honor are with me,
    enduring wealth and prosperity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My fruit is better than gold, even fine gold,
    and my yield than choice silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I walk in the way of righteousness,
    along the paths of justice,
speaker: Narrator

text:
endowing with wealth those who love me
    and filling their treasuries.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“The Lord created me at the beginning of his work,
    the first of his acts of long ago.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ages ago I was set up,
    at the first, before the beginning of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When there were no depths I was brought forth,
    when there were no springs abounding with water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before the mountains had been shaped,
    before the hills, I was brought forth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when he had not yet made earth and fields
    or the world’s first bits of soil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he established the heavens, I was there;
    when he drew a circle on the face of the deep,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when he made firm the skies above,
    when he established the fountains of the deep,
speaker: Narrator

text:
when he assigned to the sea its limit,
    so that the waters might not transgress his command,
when he marked out the foundations of the earth,
speaker: Narrator

text:
then I was beside him, like a master worker,
and I was daily his delight,
    playing before him always,
speaker: Narrator

text:
playing in his inhabited world
    and delighting in the human race.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And now, my children, listen to me:
    happy are those who keep my ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear instruction and be wise,
    and do not neglect it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Happy is the one who listens to me,
    watching daily at my gates,
    waiting beside my doors.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For whoever finds me finds life
    and obtains favor from the Lord,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but those who miss me injure themselves;
    all who hate me love death.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom has built her house;
    she has hewn her seven pillars.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She has slaughtered her animals; she has mixed her wine;
    she has also set her table.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She has sent out her female servants; she calls
    from the highest places in the town,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You who are simple, turn in here!”
    To those without sense she says,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Come, eat of my bread
    and drink of the wine I have mixed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lay aside immaturity and live,
    and walk in the way of insight.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever corrects a scoffer wins abuse;
    whoever rebukes the wicked gets hurt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not rebuke a scoffer, lest he hate you;
    rebuke the wise, and he will love you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give instruction to the wise, and they will become wiser still;
    teach the righteous, and they will gain in learning.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom,
    and the knowledge of the Holy One is insight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For by me your days will be multiplied,
    and years will be added to your life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you are wise, you are wise for yourself;
    if you scoff, you alone will bear it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The foolish woman is loud;
    she is ignorant and knows nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She sits at the door of her house,
    on a seat at the high places of the town,
speaker: Narrator

text:
calling to those who pass by,
    who are going straight on their way,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“You who are simple, turn in here!”
    And to those without sense she says,
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Stolen water is sweet,
    and bread eaten in secret is pleasant.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
But they do not know that the dead are there,
    that her guests are in the depths of Sheol.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The proverbs of Solomon.
A wise child makes a glad father,
    but a foolish child is a mother’s grief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Treasures gained by wickedness do not profit,
    but righteousness delivers from death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord does not let the righteous go hungry,
    but he thwarts the craving of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A slack hand causes poverty,
    but the hand of the diligent makes rich.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A child who gathers in summer is prudent,
    but a child who sleeps in harvest brings shame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blessings are on the head of the righteous,
    but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The memory of the righteous is a blessing,
    but the name of the wicked will rot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise of heart will heed commandments,
    but one with foolish lips will come to ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever walks in integrity walks securely,
    but whoever follows perverse ways will be found out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever winks the eye causes trouble,
    but one who rebukes boldly makes peace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mouth of the righteous is a fountain of life,
    but the mouth of the wicked conceals violence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hatred stirs up strife,
    but love covers all offenses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the lips of one who has understanding wisdom is found,
    but a rod is for the back of one who lacks sense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise lay up knowledge,
    but the mouth of a fool brings ruin near.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wealth of the rich is their fortress;
    the poverty of the poor is their ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wage of the righteous leads to life,
    the gain of the wicked to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever heeds instruction is on the path to life,
    but one who rejects a rebuke goes astray.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lying lips conceal hatred,
    and whoever utters slander is a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When words are many, transgression is not lacking,
    but the prudent are restrained in speech.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The tongue of the righteous is choice silver;
    the mind of the wicked is of little worth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lips of the righteous feed many,
    but fools die for lack of sense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The blessing of the Lord makes rich,
    and toil adds nothing to it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Doing wrong is like sport to a fool,
    but wise conduct is pleasure to a person of understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What the wicked dread will come upon them,
    but the desire of the righteous will be granted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the tempest passes, the wicked are no more,
    but the righteous are established forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like vinegar to the teeth and smoke to the eyes,
    so are the lazy to their employers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fear of the Lord prolongs life,
    but the years of the wicked will be short.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The hope of the righteous ends in gladness,
    but the expectation of the wicked comes to nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The way of the Lord is a stronghold for the upright
    but destruction for evildoers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous will never totter,
    but the wicked will not remain on the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mouth of the righteous brings forth wisdom,
    but the perverse tongue will be cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lips of the righteous know what is acceptable,
    but the mouth of the wicked what is perverse.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A false balance is an abomination to the Lord,
    but an accurate weight is his delight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When pride comes, then comes disgrace,
    but wisdom is with the humble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The integrity of the upright guides them,
    but the crookedness of the treacherous destroys them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Riches do not profit in the day of wrath,
    but righteousness delivers from death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteousness of the blameless keeps their ways straight,
    but the wicked fall by their own wickedness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteousness of the upright saves them,
    but the treacherous are taken captive by their schemes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the wicked die, hope perishes,
    and the expectation of strength comes to nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous are delivered from trouble,
    and the wicked come into it instead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With their mouths the godless would destroy their neighbors,
    but by knowledge the righteous are delivered.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When it goes well with the righteous, the city rejoices,
    and when the wicked perish, there is jubilation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By the blessing of the upright a city is exalted,
    but it is overthrown by the mouth of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever belittles another lacks sense,
    but an intelligent person remains silent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A gossip goes about telling secrets,
    but one who is trustworthy in spirit keeps a confidence.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where there is no guidance, a nation falls,
    but in an abundance of counselors there is safety.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To guarantee loans for a stranger brings trouble,
    but there is safety in refusing to do so.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A gracious woman gets honor,
    but she who hates virtue is covered with shame.
The timid become destitute,
    but the aggressive gain riches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who are kind reward themselves,
    but the cruel do themselves harm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked earn no real gain,
    but those who sow righteousness get a true reward.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever is steadfast in righteousness will live,
    but whoever pursues evil will die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Crooked minds are an abomination to the Lord,
    but those of blameless ways are his delight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be assured, the wicked will not go unpunished,
    but those who are righteous will escape.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a gold ring in a pig’s snout
    is a beautiful woman without good sense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The desire of the righteous ends only in good,
    the expectation of the wicked in wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some give freely yet grow all the richer;
    others withhold what is due and only suffer want.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A generous person will be enriched,
    and one who gives water will get water.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The people curse those who hold back grain,
    but a blessing is on the head of those who sell it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever diligently seeks good seeks favor,
    but evil comes to the one who searches for it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who trust in their riches will wither,
    but the righteous will flourish like green leaves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who trouble their households will inherit wind,
    and the fool will be servant to the wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fruit of the righteous is a tree of life,
    and the wise capture souls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the righteous are repaid on earth,
    how much more the wicked and the sinner!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever loves discipline loves knowledge,
    but those who hate to be rebuked are stupid.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The good obtain favor from the Lord,
    but those who devise evil he condemns.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No one finds security by wickedness,
    but the root of the righteous will never be moved.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A good wife is the crown of her husband,
    but she who brings shame is like rottenness in his bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The thoughts of the righteous are just;
    the advice of the wicked is treacherous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of the wicked are a deadly ambush,
    but the speech of the upright delivers them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked are overthrown and are no more,
    but the house of the righteous will stand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One is commended for good sense,
    but a perverse mind is despised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to be despised and have produce
    than to be self-important and lack food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous know the needs of their animals,
    but the mercy of the wicked is cruel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who till their land will have plenty of food,
    but those who follow worthless pursuits have no sense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked covet the proceeds of wickedness,
    but the root of the righteous bears fruit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The evil are ensnared by the transgression of their lips,
    but the righteous escape from trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the fruit of the mouth one is filled with good things,
    and manual labor has its reward.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fools think their own way is right,
    but the wise listen to advice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fools show their anger at once,
    but the prudent ignore an insult.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever speaks the truth gives honest evidence,
    but a false witness speaks deceitfully.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rash words are like sword thrusts,
    but the tongue of the wise brings healing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Truthful lips endure forever,
    but a lying tongue lasts only a moment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Deceit is in the mind of those who plan evil,
    but those who counsel peace have joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No harm happens to the righteous,
    but the wicked are filled with trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lying lips are an abomination to the Lord,
    but those who act faithfully are his delight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who is clever conceals knowledge,
    but the mind of a fool broadcasts folly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The hand of the diligent will rule,
    while the lazy will be put to forced labor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anxiety weighs down the human heart,
    but a good word cheers it up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous are released from misfortune,
    but the way of the wicked leads them astray.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lazy do not roast their game,
    but the diligent obtain precious wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the path of righteousness there is life;
    in walking its path there is no death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise child loves discipline,
    but a scoffer does not listen to rebuke.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the fruit of their words good persons eat good things,
    but the desire of the treacherous is for wrongdoing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who guard their mouths preserve their lives;
    those who open wide their lips come to ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The appetite of the lazy craves and gets nothing,
    while the appetite of the diligent is richly supplied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous hate falsehood,
    but the wicked act shamefully and disgracefully.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Righteousness guards one whose way is upright,
    but sin overthrows the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some pretend to be rich yet have nothing;
    others pretend to be poor yet have great wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wealth is a ransom for a person’s life,
    but a poor person pays no attention to a rebuke.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The light of the righteous rejoices,
    but the lamp of the wicked goes out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By insolence the empty-headed person makes strife,
    but wisdom is with those who take advice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wealth hastily gotten will dwindle,
    but those who gather little by little will increase it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hope deferred makes the heart sick,
    but a desire fulfilled is a tree of life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who despise a word bring destruction on themselves,
    but those who respect a command will be rewarded.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The teaching of the wise is a fountain of life,
    so that one may avoid the snares of death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Good sense wins favor,
    but the way of the faithless is their ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The clever do all things intelligently,
    but the fool displays folly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A bad messenger brings trouble,
    but a faithful envoy, healing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Poverty and disgrace are for the one who ignores instruction,
    but one who heeds reproof is honored.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A desire realized is sweet to the soul,
    but to turn away from evil is an abomination to fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever walks with the wise becomes wise,
    but the companion of fools suffers harm.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Misfortune pursues sinners,
    but prosperity rewards the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The good leave an inheritance to their children’s children,
    but the sinner’s wealth is laid up for the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The field of the poor may yield much food,
    but it is swept away through injustice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who spare the rod hate their children,
    but those who love them are diligent to discipline them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous have enough to satisfy their appetite,
    but the belly of the wicked is empty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise woman builds her house,
    but the foolish tears it down with her own hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who walk uprightly fear the Lord,
    but one who is devious in conduct despises him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The talk of fools is a rod for their backs,
    but the lips of the wise preserve them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where there are no oxen, there is no grain;
    abundant crops come by the strength of the ox.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A faithful witness does not lie,
    but a false witness breathes out lies.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A scoffer seeks wisdom in vain,
    but knowledge is easy for one who understands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Leave the presence of a fool,
    for there you do not find words of knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is the wisdom of the clever to understand where they go,
    but the folly of fools misleads.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Fools mock at the guilt offering,
    but the upright enjoy God’s favor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The heart knows its own bitterness,
    and no stranger shares its joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The house of the wicked is destroyed,
    but the tent of the upright flourishes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is a way that seems right to a person,
    but its end is the way to death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even in laughter the heart is sad,
    and the end of joy is grief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The perverse get what their ways deserve,
    and the good, what their deeds deserve.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The simple believe everything,
    but the clever consider their steps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise are cautious and turn away from evil,
    but the fool throws off restraint and is careless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who is quick-tempered acts foolishly,
    and the schemer is hated.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The simple are adorned with folly,
    but the clever are crowned with knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The evil bow down before the good,
    the wicked at the gates of the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The poor are disliked even by their neighbors,
    but the rich have many friends.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who despise their neighbors are sinners,
    but happy are those who are kind to the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not those who plan evil err?
    Those who plan good find loyalty and faithfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In all toil there is profit,
    but mere talk leads only to poverty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The crown of the wise is their wealth,
    but folly is the garland of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A truthful witness saves lives,
    but one who utters lies is a betrayer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the fear of the Lord one has strong confidence,
    and one’s children will have a refuge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fear of the Lord is a fountain of life,
    so that one may avoid the snares of death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The glory of a king is a multitude of people;
    without people a prince is ruined.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever is slow to anger has great understanding,
    but one who has a hasty temper exalts folly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A tranquil mind gives life to the flesh,
    but jealousy makes the bones rot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who oppress the poor insult their Maker,
    but those who are kind to the needy honor him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked are overthrown by their evildoing,
    but the righteous find a refuge in their integrity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom is at home in the mind of one who has understanding,
    but it is not known in the heart of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Righteousness exalts a nation,
    but sin is a reproach to any people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A servant who deals wisely has the king’s favor,
    but his wrath falls on one who acts shamefully.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A soft answer turns away wrath,
    but a harsh word stirs up anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The tongue of the wise adorns knowledge,
    but the mouths of fools pour out folly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eyes of the Lord are in every place,
    keeping watch on the evil and the good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A gentle tongue is a tree of life,
    but perverseness in it breaks the spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fool despises a parent’s instruction,
    but the one who heeds admonition is prudent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the house of the righteous there is much treasure,
    but trouble befalls the income of the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lips of the wise spread knowledge;
    not so the minds of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination to the Lord,
    but the prayer of the upright is his delight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The way of the wicked is an abomination to the Lord,
    but he loves the one who pursues righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is severe discipline for one who forsakes the way;
    one who hates a rebuke will die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sheol and Abaddon lie open before the Lord;
    how much more human hearts!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Scoffers do not like to be rebuked;
    they will not go to the wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A glad heart makes a cheerful countenance,
    but by sorrow of heart the spirit is broken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mind of one who has understanding seeks knowledge,
    but the mouths of fools feed on folly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All the days of the poor are hard,
    but a cheerful heart has a continual feast.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better is a little with the fear of the Lord
    than great treasure and trouble with it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better is a dinner of vegetables where love is
    than a fatted ox and hatred with it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who are hot-tempered stir up strife,
    but those who are slow to anger calm contention.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The way of the lazy is overgrown with thorns,
    but the path of the upright is a level highway.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise child makes a glad father,
    but the foolish despise their mothers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Folly is a joy to one who has no sense,
    but a person of understanding walks straight ahead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Without counsel, plans go wrong,
    but with many advisers they succeed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To make an apt answer is a joy to anyone,
    and a word in season, how good it is!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For the wise the path of life leads upward,
    in order to avoid Sheol below.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord tears down the house of the proud
    but maintains the widow’s boundaries.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil plans are an abomination to the Lord,
    but gracious words are pure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those greedy for unjust gain make trouble for their households,
    but those who hate bribes will live.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mind of the righteous ponders how to answer,
    but the mouth of the wicked pours out evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord is far from the wicked,
    but he hears the prayer of the righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The light of the eyes rejoices the heart,
    and good news refreshes the body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The ear that heeds wholesome admonition
    will lodge among the wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who ignore instruction despise themselves,
    but those who heed admonition gain understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fear of the Lord is instruction in wisdom,
    and humility goes before honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The plans of the mind belong to mortals,
    but the answer of the tongue is from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All one’s ways may be pure in one’s own eyes,
    but the Lord weighs the spirit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Commit your work to the Lord,
    and your plans will be established.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord has made everything for its purpose,
    even the wicked for the day of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All those who are arrogant are an abomination to the Lord;
    be assured, they will not go unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By loyalty and faithfulness iniquity is atoned for,
    and by the fear of the Lord one avoids evil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the ways of people please the Lord,
    he causes even their enemies to be at peace with them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better is a little with righteousness
    than large income with injustice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The human mind plans the way,
    but the Lord directs the steps.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Inspired decisions are on the lips of a king;
    his mouth does not sin in judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Honest balances and scales are the Lord’s;
    all the weights in the bag are his work.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is an abomination to kings to do evil,
    for the throne is established by righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Righteous lips are the delight of a king,
    and he loves those who speak what is right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A king’s wrath is a messenger of death,
    and whoever is wise will appease it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the light of a king’s face there is life,
    and his favor is like the clouds that bring the spring rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How much better to get wisdom than gold!
    To get understanding is to be chosen rather than silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The highway of the upright avoids evil;
    those who guard their way preserve their lives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pride goes before destruction
    and a haughty spirit before a fall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is better to be of a lowly spirit among the poor
    than to divide the spoil with the proud.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who are attentive to a matter will prosper,
    and happy are those who trust in the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wise of heart is called perceptive,
    and pleasant speech increases persuasiveness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom is a fountain of life to one who has it,
    but folly is the punishment of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mind of the wise makes their speech judicious
    and adds persuasiveness to their lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pleasant words are like a honeycomb,
    sweetness to the soul and health to the body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sometimes there is a way that seems to be right,
    but in the end it is the way to death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The appetite of workers works for them;
    their hunger urges them on.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Scoundrels concoct evil,
    and their speech is like a scorching fire.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A perverse person spreads strife,
    and a whisperer separates close friends.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The violent entice their neighbors
    and lead them in a way that is not good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who winks the eyes plans perverse things;
    one who compresses the lips brings evil to pass.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gray hair is a crown of glory;
    it is gained in a righteous life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who is slow to anger is better than the mighty,
    and one whose temper is controlled than one who captures a city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lot is cast into the lap,
    but the decision is the Lord’s alone.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better is a dry morsel with quiet
    than a house full of feasting with strife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A slave who deals wisely will rule over a child who acts shamefully
    and will share the inheritance as one of the family.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The crucible is for silver and the furnace for gold,
    but the Lord tests the heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An evildoer listens to wicked lips,
    and a liar gives heed to a mischievous tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who mock the poor insult their Maker;
    those who are glad at calamity will not go unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Grandchildren are the crown of the aged,
    and the glory of children is their parents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Excess speech is not becoming to a fool;
    still less is false speech to a ruler.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A bribe is like a magic stone in the eyes of those who give it;
    wherever they turn they prosper.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who forgives an affront fosters friendship,
    but one who dwells on disputes will alienate a friend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A rebuke strikes deeper into a discerning person
    than a hundred blows into a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil people seek only rebellion,
    but a cruel messenger will be sent against them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to meet a she-bear robbed of its cubs
    than to confront a fool immersed in folly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil will not depart from the house
    of one who returns evil for good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The beginning of strife is like letting out water,
    so stop before the quarrel breaks out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who justifies the wicked and one who condemns the righteous
    are both alike an abomination to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Why should fools have a price in hand
    to buy wisdom when they have no mind to learn?
speaker: Narrator

text:
A friend loves at all times,
    and kinsfolk are born to share adversity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is senseless to give a pledge,
    to become surety for a neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who loves transgression loves strife;
    one who builds a high threshold invites broken bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The crooked of mind do not prosper,
    and the perverse of tongue fall into calamity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The one who fathers a fool gets trouble;
    the parent of a fool has no joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A cheerful heart is a good medicine,
    but a downcast spirit dries up the bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked accept a concealed bribe
    to pervert the ways of justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The discerning person looks to wisdom,
    but the eyes of a fool to the ends of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Foolish children are a grief to their father
    and bitterness to her who bore them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To impose a fine on the innocent is not right
    or to flog the noble for their integrity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who spares words is knowledgeable;
    one who is cool in spirit has understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even fools who keep silent are considered wise;
    when they close their lips, they are deemed intelligent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The one who lives alone is self-indulgent,
    showing contempt for all sound judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fool takes no pleasure in understanding,
    but only in expressing personal opinion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When wickedness comes, contempt comes also,
    and with dishonor comes disgrace.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of the mouth are deep waters;
    the fountain of wisdom is a gushing stream.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is not right to be partial to the guilty
    or to subvert the innocent in judgment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fool’s lips bring strife,
    and a fool’s mouth invites a flogging.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mouths of fools are their ruin,
    and their lips a snare to themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of a whisperer are like delicious morsels;
    they go down into the inner parts of the body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who is slack in work
    is close kin to a vandal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The name of the Lord is a strong tower;
    the righteous run into it and are safe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wealth of the rich is their strong city;
    in their imagination it is like a high wall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before destruction one’s heart is haughty,
    but humility goes before honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If one gives answer before hearing,
    it is folly and shame.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The human spirit will endure sickness,
    but a broken spirit—who can bear?
speaker: Narrator

text:
An intelligent mind acquires knowledge,
    and the ear of the wise seeks knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A gift opens doors;
    it gives access to the great.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The one who first states a case seems right,
    until the other comes and cross-examines.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Casting the lot puts an end to disputes
    and decides between powerful contenders.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An ally offended is stronger than a city;
    such quarreling is like the bars of a castle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the fruit of the mouth one’s stomach is satisfied;
    the yield of the lips brings satisfaction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Death and life are in the power of the tongue,
    and those who love it will eat its fruits.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He who finds a wife finds a good thing
    and obtains favor from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The poor use entreaties,
    but the rich answer roughly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Some friends play at friendship,
    but a true friend sticks closer than one’s sibling.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better the poor walking in integrity
    than one perverse of speech who is a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Desire without knowledge is not good,
    and one who moves too hurriedly misses the way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One’s own folly leads to ruin,
    yet the heart rages against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wealth brings many friends,
    but the poor are left friendless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A false witness will not go unpunished,
    and a liar will not escape.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many seek the favor of the generous,
    and everyone is a friend to a giver of gifts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the poor are hated even by their kin,
    how much more are they shunned by their friends!
When they call after them, they are not there.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To get wisdom is to love oneself;
    to keep understanding is to prosper.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A false witness will not go unpunished,
    and the liar will perish.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is not fitting for a fool to live in luxury,
    much less for a slave to rule over princes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those with good sense are slow to anger,
    and it is their glory to overlook an offense.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A king’s anger is like the growling of a lion,
    but his favor is like dew on the grass.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A stupid child is ruin to a father,
    and a wife’s quarreling is a continual dripping of rain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
House and wealth are inherited from parents,
    but a prudent wife is from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Laziness brings on deep sleep;
    an idle person will suffer hunger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who keep the commandment will live;
    those who are heedless of their ways will die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever is kind to the poor lends to the Lord
    and will be repaid in full.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Discipline your children while there is hope;
    do not set your heart on their destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A violent-tempered person will pay the penalty;
    if you effect a rescue, you will only have to do it again.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to advice and accept instruction,
    that you may gain wisdom for the future.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The human mind may devise many plans,
    but it is the purpose of the Lord that will be established.
speaker: Narrator

text:
What is desirable in a person is loyalty,
    and it is better to be poor than a liar.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
The lazy person buries a hand in the dish
    and will not even bring it back to the mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Strike a scoffer, and the simple will learn prudence;
    reprove the intelligent, and they will gain knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who do violence to their father and chase away their mother
    are children who cause shame and bring reproach.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, stop ignoring instruction,
    straying from words of knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A worthless witness mocks at justice,
    and the mouth of the wicked devours iniquity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Punishments are prepared for scoffers
    and flogging for the backs of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wine is a mocker, strong drink a brawler,
    and whoever is led astray by it is not wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The dread anger of a king is like the growling of a lion;
    anyone who provokes him to anger forfeits life itself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is honorable to refrain from strife,
    but every fool is quick to quarrel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lazy person does not plow in season;
    harvest comes, and there is nothing to be found.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The purposes in the human mind are like deep water,
    but the intelligent will draw them out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many proclaim themselves loyal,
    but who can find one worthy of trust?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous walk in integrity—
    happy are the children who follow them!
speaker: Narrator

text:
A king who sits on the throne of judgment
    winnows all evil with his eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can say, “I have made my heart clean;
    I am pure from my sin”?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Diverse weights and diverse measures
    are both alike an abomination to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even children make themselves known by their acts,
    by whether what they do is pure and right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The hearing ear and the seeing eye—
    the Lord has made them both.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not love sleep, or else you will come to poverty;
    open your eyes, and you will have plenty of bread.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Bad, bad,” says the buyer,
    then goes away and boasts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There is gold and abundance of costly stones,
    but the lips informed by knowledge are a precious jewel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take the garment of one who has given surety for a stranger;
    seize the pledge given as surety for foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bread gained by deceit is sweet,
    but afterward the mouth will be full of gravel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Plans are established by taking advice;
    wage war by following wise guidance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A gossip reveals secrets;
    therefore do not associate with a babbler.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you curse father or mother,
    your lamp will go out in utter darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An estate quickly acquired in the beginning
    will not be blessed in the end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not say, “I will repay evil”;
    wait for the Lord, and he will help you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Differing weights are an abomination to the Lord,
    and false scales are not good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All our steps are ordered by the Lord;
    how then can we understand our own ways?
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is a snare for one to say rashly, “It is holy,”
    and begin to reflect only after making a vow.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wise king winnows the wicked
    and drives the wheel over them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The human spirit is the lamp of the Lord,
    searching every inmost part.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Loyalty and faithfulness preserve the king,
    and his throne is upheld by righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The glory of youths is their strength,
    but the beauty of the aged is their gray hair.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blows that wound cleanse away evil;
    beatings make clean the innermost parts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The king’s heart is a stream of water in the hand of the Lord;
    he turns it wherever he will.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All deeds are right in the sight of the doer,
    but the Lord weighs the heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To do righteousness and justice
    is more acceptable to the Lord than sacrifice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Haughty eyes and a proud heart—
    the lamp of the wicked—are sin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The plans of the diligent lead surely to abundance,
    but everyone who is hasty comes only to want.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The getting of treasures by a lying tongue
    is a fleeting vapor and a snare of death.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The violence of the wicked will sweep them away
    because they refuse to do what is just.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The way of the guilty is crooked,
    but the conduct of the pure is right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is better to live in a corner of the housetop
    than in a house shared with a contentious wife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The souls of the wicked desire evil;
    their neighbors find no mercy in their eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a scoffer is punished, the simple become wiser;
    when the wise are instructed, they increase in knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Righteous One observes the house of the wicked;
    he casts the wicked down to ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you close your ear to the cry of the poor,
    you will cry out and not be heard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A gift in secret averts anger,
    and a concealed bribe, strong wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When justice is done, it is a joy to the righteous
    but dismay to evildoers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever wanders from the way of understanding
    will rest in the assembly of the dead.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever loves pleasure will suffer want;
    whoever loves wine and oil will not be rich.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked is a ransom for the righteous
    and the faithless for the upright.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is better to live in a desert land
    than with a contentious and fretful wife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Precious treasure remains in the house of the wise,
    but the fool devours it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever pursues righteousness and kindness
    will find life and honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One wise person went up against a city of warriors
    and brought down the stronghold in which they trusted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To watch over mouth and tongue
    is to keep out of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The proud, haughty person, named Scoffer,
    acts with arrogant pride.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The craving of the lazy person is fatal,
    for lazy hands refuse to labor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
All day long the wicked covet,
    but the righteous give and do not hold back.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination;
    how much more when brought with evil intent.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A false witness will perish,
    but a good listener will testify successfully.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked put on a bold face,
    but the upright give thought to their ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No wisdom, no understanding, no counsel
    can avail against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The horse is made ready for the day of battle,
    but the victory belongs to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A good name is to be chosen rather than great riches,
    and favor is better than silver or gold.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rich and the poor have this in common:
    the Lord is the maker of them all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The clever see danger and hide,
    but the simple go on and suffer for it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The reward for humility and fear of the Lord
    is riches and honor and life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Thorns and snares are in the way of the perverse;
    the cautious will keep far from them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Train children in the right way,
    and when old, they will not stray.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rich rule over the poor,
    and the borrower is the slave of the lender.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever sows injustice will reap calamity,
    and the rod of anger will fail.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who are generous are blessed,
    for they share their bread with the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Drive out a scoffer, and strife goes out;
    quarreling and abuse will cease.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who love a pure heart and are gracious in speech
    will have the king as a friend.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eyes of the Lord keep watch over knowledge,
    but he overthrows the words of the faithless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lazy person says, “There is a lion outside!
    I shall be killed in the streets!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The mouth of a loose woman is a deep pit;
    he with whom the Lord is angry falls into it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Folly is bound up in the heart of a child,
    but the rod of discipline drives it far away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Oppressing the poor in order to enrich oneself,
    and giving to the rich, will lead only to loss.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of the wise:
Incline your ear and hear my words
    and apply your mind to my teaching,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for it will be pleasant if you keep them within you,
    if all of them are ready on your lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So that your trust may be in the Lord,
    I have made them known to you today, yes, to you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have I not written for you thirty sayings
    of admonition and knowledge,
speaker: Narrator

text:
to show you what is right and true,
    so that you may give a true answer to those who sent you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not rob the poor because they are poor
    or crush the afflicted at the gate,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the Lord pleads their cause
    and despoils of life those who despoil them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Make no friends with those given to anger,
    and do not associate with hotheads,
speaker: Narrator

text:
lest you learn their ways
    and entangle yourself in a snare.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not be one of those who give pledges,
    who become surety for debts.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have nothing with which to pay,
    why should your bed be taken from under you?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not remove the ancient landmark
    that your ancestors set up.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
When you sit down to eat with an official,
    observe carefully what is before you,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and put a knife to your throat
    if you have a big appetite.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not desire an official’s delicacies,
    for they are deceptive food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not wear yourself out to get rich;
    be wise enough to desist.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Do not eat the bread of the stingy;
    do not desire their delicacies,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for like a hair in the throat, so are they.
    “Eat and drink!” they say to you,
    but they do not mean it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will vomit up the little you have eaten,
    and you will waste your pleasant words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not speak in the hearing of a fool,
    who will only despise the wisdom of your words.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not remove an ancient landmark
    or encroach on the fields of orphans,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for their vindicator is strong;
    he will plead their cause against you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Apply your mind to instruction
    and your ear to words of knowledge.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not withhold discipline from your children;
    if you beat them with a rod, they will not die.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you beat them with the rod,
    you will save their lives from Sheol.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, if your heart is wise,
    my heart also will be glad.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My soul will rejoice
    when your lips speak what is right.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not let your heart envy sinners,
    but always continue in the fear of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely there is a future,
    and your hope will not be cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear, my child, and be wise,
    and direct your mind in the way.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not be among winebibbers
    or among gluttonous eaters of meat,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the drunkard and the glutton will come to poverty,
    and drowsiness will clothe them with rags.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Listen to your father who begot you,
    and do not despise your mother when she is old.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Buy truth, and do not sell it;
    buy wisdom, instruction, and understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The father of the righteous will greatly rejoice;
    he who fathers a wise son will be glad in him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let your father and mother be glad;
    let her who bore you rejoice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, give me your heart,
    and let your eyes observe my ways.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For a prostitute is a deep pit;
    an adulteress is a narrow well.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She lies in wait like a robber
    and increases the number of the faithless.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has woe? Who has sorrow?
    Who has strife? Who has complaining?
Who has wounds without cause?
    Who has redness of eyes?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who linger late over wine,
    those who keep trying mixed wines.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not look at wine when it is red,
    when it sparkles in the cup
    and goes down smoothly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At the last it bites like a serpent
    and stings like an adder.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Your eyes will see strange things,
    and your mind utter perverse things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will be like one who lies down in the midst of the sea,
    like one who lies on the top of a mast.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“They struck me,” you will say, “but I was not hurt;
    they beat me, but I did not feel it.
When shall I awake?
    I will seek another drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not envy the wicked,
    nor desire to be with them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for their minds devise violence,
    and their lips talk of mischief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By wisdom a house is built,
    and by understanding it is established;
speaker: Narrator

text:
by knowledge the rooms are filled
    with all precious and pleasant riches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wise warriors are mightier than strong ones
    and those who have knowledge than those who have strength,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for by wise guidance you can wage your war,
    and in abundance of counselors there is victory.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wisdom is too high for fools;
    in the gate they do not open their mouths.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever plans to do evil
    will be called a mischief-maker.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The devising of folly is sin,
    and the scoffer is an abomination to all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you faint in the day of adversity,
    your strength being small;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if you hold back from rescuing those taken away to death,
    those who go staggering to the slaughter;
speaker: Narrator

text:
if you say, “Look, we did not know this”—
    does not he who weighs the heart perceive it?
Does not he who keeps watch over your soul know it?
    And will he not repay all according to their deeds?
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, eat honey, for it is good,
    and the drippings of the honeycomb are sweet to your taste.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Do not lie in wait like an outlaw against the home of the righteous;
    do no violence to the place where the righteous live;
speaker: Narrator

text:
for though they fall seven times, they will rise again,
    but the wicked are overthrown by calamity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not rejoice when your enemies fall,
    and do not let your heart be glad when they stumble,
speaker: Narrator

text:
lest the Lord see it and be displeased
    and turn away his anger from them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not fret because of evildoers.
    Do not envy the wicked,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for the evil have no future;
    the lamp of the wicked will go out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
My child, fear the Lord and the king,
    and do not disobey either of them,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for disaster comes from them suddenly,
    and who knows the ruin that both can bring?
speaker: Narrator

text:
These also are sayings of the wise:
Partiality in judging is not good.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever says to the wicked, “You are innocent,”
    will be cursed by peoples, abhorred by nations,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but those who rebuke the wicked will have delight,
    and a good blessing will come upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who gives an honest answer
    gives a kiss on the lips.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Do not be a witness against your neighbor without cause,
    and do not deceive with your lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not say, “I will do to others as they have done to me;
    I will pay them back for what they have done.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
I passed by the field of one who was lazy,
    by the vineyard of a stupid person,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Then I saw and considered it;
    I looked and received instruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A little sleep, a little slumber,
    a little folding of the hands to rest,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and poverty will come upon you like a robber,
    and want, like an armed warrior.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are other proverbs of Solomon that the officials of King Hezekiah of Judah copied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is the glory of God to conceal things,
    but the glory of kings is to search things out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like the heavens for height, like the earth for depth,
    so the mind of kings is unsearchable.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take away the dross from the silver,
    and the smith has material for a vessel;
speaker: Narrator

text:
take away the wicked from the presence of the king,
    and his throne will be established in righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not put yourself forward in the king’s presence
    or stand in the place of the great,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for it is better to be told, “Come up here,”
    than to be put lower in the presence of a noble.
What your eyes have seen
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Argue your case with your neighbor directly,
    and do not disclose another’s secret,
speaker: Narrator

text:
or else someone who hears you will bring shame upon you,
    and your ill repute will have no end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A word fitly spoken
    is like apples of gold in a setting of silver.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a gold ring or an ornament of gold
    is a wise rebuke to a listening ear.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Like clouds and wind without rain
    is one who boasts of a gift never given.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With patience a ruler may be persuaded,
    and a soft tongue can break bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have found honey, eat only enough for you,
    lest, having too much, you vomit it up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let your foot be seldom in your neighbor’s house,
    lest the neighbor become weary of you and hate you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a war club, a sword, or a sharp arrow
    is one who bears false witness against a neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a bad tooth or a lame foot
    is trust in a faithless person in time of trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like vinegar on a wound
    is one who sings songs to a heavy heart.
Like a moth in clothing or a worm in wood,
    sorrow gnaws at the human heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If your enemies are hungry, give them bread to eat,
    and if they are thirsty, give them water to drink,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for you will heap coals of fire on their heads,
    and the Lord will reward you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The north wind produces rain,
    and a backbiting tongue, angry looks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is better to live in a corner of the housetop
    than in a house shared with a contentious wife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like cold water to a thirsty soul,
    so is good news from a far country.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a muddied spring or a polluted fountain
