    are the righteous who give way before the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is not good to eat much honey
    or to seek honor on top of honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a city breached, without walls,
    is one who lacks self-control.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like snow in summer or rain in harvest,
    so honor is not fitting for a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a sparrow in its flitting, like a swallow in its flying,
    an undeserved curse goes nowhere.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey,
    and a rod for the back of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not answer fools according to their folly,
    lest you be a fool yourself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Answer fools according to their folly,
    lest they be wise in their own eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is like cutting off one’s foot and drinking down violence,
    to send a message by a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The legs of a lame person hang limp;
    so does a proverb in the mouth of a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is like binding a stone in a sling
    to give honor to a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a thornbush brandished by the hand of a drunkard
    is a proverb in the mouth of a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like an archer who wounds everybody
    is one who hires a passing fool or drunkard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a dog that returns to its vomit
    is a fool who reverts to his folly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you see people wise in their own eyes?
    There is more hope for fools than for them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lazy person says, “There is a lion in the road!
    There is a lion in the streets!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a door turns on its hinges,
    so does a lazy person in bed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lazy person buries a hand in the dish
    and is too tired to bring it back to the mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The lazy person is wiser in self-esteem
    than seven who can answer discreetly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like someone who takes a passing dog by the ears
    is one who meddles in the quarrel of another.
speaker: Narrator

text: Like a maniac who shoots deadly firebrands and arrows,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so is one who deceives a neighbor
    and says, “I am only joking!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
For lack of wood the fire goes out,
    and where there is no whisperer, quarreling ceases.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As charcoal is to hot embers and wood to fire,
    so is a quarrelsome person for kindling strife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of a whisperer are like delicious morsels;
    they go down into the inner parts of the body.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like the glaze covering an earthen vessel
    are smooth lips with an evil heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An enemy dissembles in speaking
    while harboring deceit within;
speaker: Narrator

text:
when an enemy speaks graciously, do not believe it,
    for there are seven abominations concealed within;
speaker: Narrator

text:
though hatred is covered with guile,
    the enemy’s wickedness will be exposed in the assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever digs a pit will fall into it,
    and a stone will come back on the one who starts it rolling.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lying tongue hates its victims,
    and a flattering mouth works ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not boast about tomorrow,
    for you do not know what a day may bring.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let another praise you and not your own mouth,
    a stranger and not your own lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A stone is heavy, and sand is weighty,
    but a fool’s provocation is heavier than both.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wrath is cruel, anger is overwhelming,
    but who is able to stand before jealousy?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better is open rebuke
    than hidden love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Well meant are the wounds a friend inflicts,
    but profuse are the kisses of an enemy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sated appetite spurns honey,
    but to a ravenous appetite even the bitter is sweet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a bird that strays from its nest
    is one who strays from home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Perfume and incense make the heart glad,
    but the soul is torn by trouble.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not forsake your friend or the friend of your parent;
    do not go to the house of your kindred in the day of your calamity.
Better is a neighbor who is nearby
    than kindred who are far away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be wise, my child, and make my heart glad,
    so that I may answer whoever reproaches me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The clever see danger and hide,
    but the simple go on and suffer for it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Take the garment of one who has given surety for a stranger;
    seize the pledge given as surety for foreigners.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever blesses a neighbor with a loud voice,
    rising early in the morning,
    will be counted as cursing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A continual dripping on a rainy day
    and a contentious wife are alike;
speaker: Narrator

text:
to restrain her is to restrain the wind
    or to grasp oil in the right hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Iron sharpens iron,
    and one person sharpens the wits of another.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anyone who tends a fig tree will eat its fruit,
    and anyone who takes care of a master will be honored.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Just as water reflects the face,
    so one human heart reflects another.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied,
    and human eyes are never satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The crucible is for silver, and the furnace is for gold,
    so a person is tested by being praised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Crush a fool in a mortar with a pestle
    along with crushed grain,
    but the folly will not be driven out.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Know well the condition of your flocks,
    and give attention to your herds,
speaker: Narrator

text:
for riches do not last forever,
    nor a crown for all generations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the grass is gone, and new growth appears,
    and the herbage of the mountains is gathered,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the lambs will provide your clothing,
    and the goats the price of a field;
speaker: Narrator

text:
there will be enough goats’ milk for your food,
    for the food of your household
    and nourishment for your female servants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The wicked flee when no one pursues,
    but the righteous are as bold as a lion.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
A poor person who oppresses the poor
    is a beating rain that leaves no food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who forsake the law praise the wicked,
    but those who keep the law struggle against them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The evil do not understand justice,
    but those who seek the Lord understand it completely.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to be poor and walk in integrity
    than to be crooked in one’s ways even though rich.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who keep the law are wise children,
    but companions of gluttons shame their parents.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who augments wealth by exorbitant interest
    gathers it for another who is kind to the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When one will not listen to the law,
    even one’s prayers are an abomination.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who mislead the upright into evil ways
    will fall into pits of their own making,
    but the blameless will have a goodly inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rich is wise in self-esteem,
    but an intelligent poor person sees through the pose.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the righteous rejoice, there is great glory,
    but when the wicked prevail, people go into hiding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
No one who conceals transgressions will prosper,
    but one who confesses and forsakes them will obtain mercy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Happy is the one who is never without fear,
    but one who is hard-hearted will fall into calamity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a roaring lion or a charging bear
    is a wicked ruler over a poor people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A ruler who lacks understanding is a cruel oppressor,
    but one who hates unjust gain will enjoy a long life.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
One who walks in integrity will be safe,
    but whoever follows crooked ways will fall into the Pit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anyone who tills the land will have plenty of bread,
    but one who follows worthless pursuits will have plenty of poverty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The faithful will abound with blessings,
    but one who is in a hurry to be rich will not go unpunished.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To show partiality is not good,
    yet for a piece of bread a person may do wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The miser is in a hurry to get rich
    and does not know that loss is sure to come.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever rebukes a person will afterward find more favor
    than one who flatters with the tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anyone who robs father or mother
    and says, “That is no crime,”
    is partner to a thug.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The greedy person stirs up strife,
    but whoever trusts in the Lord will be enriched.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who trust in their own wits are fools,
    but those who walk in wisdom come through safely.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever gives to the poor will lack nothing,
    but one who turns a blind eye will get many a curse.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the wicked prevail, people go into hiding,
    but when they perish, the righteous increase.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who is often reproved, yet remains stubborn,
    will suddenly be broken beyond healing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the righteous are in authority, the people rejoice,
    but when the wicked rule, the people groan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A child who loves wisdom makes a parent glad,
    but a companion of prostitutes destroys wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By justice a king gives stability to the land,
    but one who makes heavy exactions ruins it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever flatters a neighbor
    is spreading a net for the neighbor’s feet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In the transgression of the evil there is a snare,
    but the righteous sing and rejoice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The righteous know the rights of the poor;
    the wicked have no such understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Scoffers set a city aflame,
    but the wise turn away wrath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If the wise go to law with fools,
    there is ranting and ridicule without relief.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The bloodthirsty hate the blameless,
    and they seek the life of the upright.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fool gives full vent to anger,
    but the wise quietly holds it back.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a ruler listens to falsehood,
    all his officials will be wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The poor and the oppressor have this in common:
    the Lord gives light to the eyes of both.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a king judges the poor with equity,
    his throne will be established forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rod and reproof give wisdom,
    but a mother is disgraced by a neglected child.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When the wicked are in authority, transgression increases,
    but the righteous will look upon their downfall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Discipline your children, and they will give you rest;
    they will give delight to your heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Where there is no prophecy, the people cast off restraint,
    but happy are those who keep the law.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By mere words slaves are not disciplined,
    for though they understand, they will not give heed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do you see someone who is hasty in speech?
    There is more hope for a fool than for anyone like that.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A slave pampered from childhood
    will come to a bad end.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One given to anger stirs up strife,
    and the hothead causes much transgression.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person’s pride will bring humiliation,
    but one who is lowly in spirit will obtain honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To be a partner of a thief is to hate one’s own life;
    one hears the victim’s curse but discloses nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fear of others lays a snare,
    but one who trusts in the Lord is secure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many seek the favor of a ruler,
    but it is from the Lord that one gets justice.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The unjust are an abomination to the righteous,
    but the upright are an abomination to the wicked.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Surely I am too stupid to be human;
    I do not have human understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I have not learned wisdom,
    nor have I knowledge of the holy ones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who has ascended to heaven and come down?
    Who has gathered the wind in the hollow of the hand?
Who has wrapped up the waters in a garment?
    Who has established all the ends of the earth?
What is the person’s name?
    And what is the name of the person’s child?
    Surely you know!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Every word of God proves true;
    he is a shield to those who take refuge in him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not add to his words,
    lest he rebuke you, and you be found a liar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Two things I ask of you;
    do not deny them to me before I die:
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
lest I be full and deny you
    and say, “Who is the Lord?”
or I be poor and steal
    and profane the name of my God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not slander a servant to a master,
    lest the servant curse you, and you be held guilty.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are those who curse their fathers
    and do not bless their mothers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are those who are pure in their own eyes,
    yet are not cleansed of their filthiness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are those—how lofty are their eyes,
    how high their eyelids lift!—
speaker: Narrator

text:
there are those whose teeth are swords,
    whose teeth are knives
to devour the poor from off the earth,
    the needy from among mortals.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Sheol, the barren womb,
    the earth ever-thirsty for water,
    and the fire that never says, “Enough.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eye that mocks a father
    and scorns to obey a mother
will be pecked out by the ravens of the valley
    and eaten by the vultures.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Three things are too wonderful for me;
    four I do not understand:
speaker: Narrator

text:
the way of an eagle in the sky,
    the way of a snake on a rock,
the way of a ship on the high seas,
    and the way of a man with a woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the way of an adulteress:
    she eats and wipes her mouth
    and says, “I have done no wrong.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Under three things the earth trembles;
    under four it cannot bear up:
speaker: Narrator

text:
a slave when he becomes king
    and a fool when glutted with food,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a contemptible woman when she gets a husband
    and a maid when she supplants her mistress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Four things on earth are small,
    yet they are exceedingly wise:
speaker: Narrator

text:
the ants are a people without strength,
    yet they provide their food in the summer;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the badgers are a people without power,
    yet they make their homes in the rocks;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the locusts have no king,
    yet all of them march in rank;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the lizard can be grasped in the hand,
    yet it is found in kings’ palaces.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Three things are stately in their stride;
    four are stately in their gait:
speaker: Narrator

text:
the lion, which is mightiest among wild animals
    and does not turn back before any;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the strutting rooster, the he-goat,
    and a king against whom none can stand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you have been foolish, exalting yourself,
    or if you have been devising evil,
    put your hand on your mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For as pressing milk produces curds
    and pressing the nose produces blood,
    so pressing anger produces strife.
speaker: Narrator

text: The words of King Lemuel. An oracle that his mother taught him:
speaker: Narrator

text:
No, my son! No, son of my womb!
    No, son of my vows!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not give your strength to women,
    your ways to those who destroy kings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It is not for kings, O Lemuel,
    it is not for kings to drink wine
    or for rulers to desire strong drink,
speaker: Narrator

text:
lest they drink and forget what has been decreed
    and pervert the rights of all the afflicted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give strong drink to one who is perishing
    and wine to those in bitter distress;
speaker: Narrator

text:
let them drink and forget their poverty
    and remember their misery no more.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Speak out for those who cannot speak,
    for the rights of all the destitute.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Speak out; judge righteously;
    defend the rights of the poor and needy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A woman of strength who can find?
    She is far more precious than jewels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The heart of her husband trusts in her,
    and he will have no lack of gain.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She does him good and not harm
    all the days of her life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She seeks wool and flax
    and works with willing hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is like the ships of the merchant;
    she brings her food from far away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She rises while it is still night
    and provides food for her household
    and tasks for her female servants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She considers a field and buys it;
    with the fruit of her hands she plants a vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She girds herself with strength
    and makes her arms strong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She perceives that her merchandise is profitable.
    Her lamp does not go out at night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She puts her hands to the distaff,
    and her hands hold the spindle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She opens her hand to the poor
    and reaches out her hands to the needy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is not afraid for her household when it snows,
    for all her household are clothed in crimson.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She makes herself coverings;
    her clothing is fine linen and purple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her husband is known in the city gates,
    taking his seat among the elders of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She makes linen garments and sells them;
    she supplies the merchant with sashes.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Strength and dignity are her clothing,
    and she laughs at the time to come.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She opens her mouth with wisdom,
    and the teaching of kindness is on her tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She looks well to the ways of her household
    and does not eat the bread of idleness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her children rise up and call her happy;
    her husband, too, and he praises her:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Many women have done excellently,
    but you surpass them all.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Charm is deceitful and beauty is vain,
    but a woman who fears the Lord is to be praised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give her a share in the fruit of her hands,
    and let her works praise her in the city gates.
speaker: Narrator
